name: Amazon
description: Amazon is the world's largest e-commerce platform offering millions of products across various categories. Users can browse and search for products, read customer reviews, compare prices, and add items to their shopping cart. The platform provides features like Prime membership for fast shipping, wish lists for saving items, order tracking, and easy returns. Customers can also manage their account settings, payment methods, addresses, and view their purchase history.
suitability_reasoning: Amazon’s core workflows are structured CRUD processes over highly synthesizable entities (users, products, inventory, carts, orders, payments, shipments, returns, reviews). A simulated environment can realistically model the end-to-end commerce lifecycle with state transitions and relationships in a SQLite schema. Some parts (true large-scale search ranking, fraud detection, real carrier integrations, and personalized recommendations) are not meaningfully reproducible, but they are not required to simulate the main user tasks.
simulatable_features: User account creation/login and profile management
Address book CRUD (shipping/billing addresses)
Payment method management (store tokenized/fictional cards, gift cards, balances)
Product catalog browsing by category/brand and basic attribute filtering
Product detail pages (title, price, images as URLs/metadata, variants, availability)
Inventory/stock status per SKU and warehouse (simple allocation rules)
Shopping cart CRUD (add/remove/update quantity, saved for later)
Checkout flow (select address, shipping option, payment method, place order)
Order management (view orders, order status state machine, invoices/receipts metadata)
Shipping/fulfillment simulation (shipment creation, tracking events timeline, delivery dates)
Wish lists and registries CRUD (create list, add/remove items, share link)
Customer reviews/ratings CRUD and aggregation (average rating, helpful votes)
Returns and refunds workflows (initiate return, return labels as metadata, refund status)
Promotions/coupons CRUD (apply code, eligibility rules, discount calculation)
Prime-like membership subscription (plan, renewal date, benefits flags)
Customer support cases (create ticket, message thread, resolution status)
non_simulatable_features: Real-world search quality at Amazon scale (ranking, relevance, autocomplete learned from behavior)
Personalized recommendations and ML-driven ranking ("Customers also bought", home feed personalization)
Real payment processing, card network authorization, fraud detection, chargebacks
Real-time integration with shipping carriers and accurate tracking data
Dynamic pricing and marketplace competition behavior based on real sellers and demand
Authenticity guarantees and real product/media content (official images/videos, brand assets)
A-to-z guarantee, regulatory/compliance processes, and dispute arbitration at real-world fidelity

name: YouTube
description: YouTube is the leading video sharing and streaming platform with billions of videos. Users can watch content ranging from educational tutorials to entertainment, upload their own videos, and build channels. The platform supports subscribing to favorite creators, creating and managing playlists, commenting on videos, and engaging with the community through likes and shares. It also offers features like video quality settings, subtitles, and personalized recommendations based on viewing history.
suitability_reasoning: YouTube’s core value is hosting/streaming video and delivering high-quality discovery and recommendations—capabilities that depend on large-scale media storage/encoding/CDN delivery and ML-driven ranking, which are not meaningfully synthesizable in a lightweight simulated API. However, many surrounding product surfaces are structured CRUD workflows (channels, subscriptions, playlists, comments, likes, basic metadata) that can be realistically synthesized and exposed via REST APIs backed by SQLite.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update settings, locale, preferences flags)
Channel creation and management (channel metadata, branding fields, owner linkage)
Video metadata management (title, description, tags, category, visibility, upload records, publish timestamps)
Library management (watch history records, liked videos list, saved-for-later)
Subscriptions (subscribe/unsubscribe to channels, notification preference state)
Playlists CRUD (create/update/delete playlists, add/remove/reorder playlist items, privacy settings)
Comments and replies CRUD (create/edit/delete, threading, timestamps)
Reactions/engagement state (like/dislike toggles, counts as derived fields, share event logs)
Captions/subtitles metadata (track language, label, availability; store text as short synthetic samples)
Video settings states (quality preference flags, playback settings, default caption settings)
Search over synthetic catalog using simple filters (keyword match, category filter, sorting by date/views)
Moderation/reporting workflows (report records, status, reviewer notes, takedown state transitions)
non_simulatable_features: Actual video hosting/streaming pipeline (uploading large media, transcoding, adaptive bitrate streaming, CDN delivery)
Realistic content catalog at internet scale and associated copyright/content ID matching
Personalized recommendations and home feed ranking based on ML models and massive interaction graphs
Accurate, real-world search ranking and query understanding comparable to production YouTube
Auto-generated captions, translation, and speech-to-text at production quality
Live streaming at scale (real-time ingest, latency, chat synchronization, stream health analytics)
Ad serving/auction dynamics and revenue optimization (real-time bidding, targeting, pacing)
Abuse/spam detection and safety systems relying on ML and large-scale signals

name: GitHub
description: GitHub is the premier code hosting platform used by millions of developers worldwide for version control and collaboration. Users can create repositories, manage branches, commit code changes, and track project versions using Git. The platform facilitates team collaboration through pull requests, code reviews, issue tracking, and project boards. It also supports CI/CD workflows, security scanning, and documentation hosting through GitHub Pages.
suitability_reasoning: Many GitHub workflows map cleanly to structured CRUD data (repos, issues, PRs, users, permissions, projects) and can be synthesized realistically in a SQLite-backed REST API. However, core differentiators depend on non-trivial Git semantics and content (actual git object model, diffs/merges, conflict resolution), plus CI execution, security scanning, and rich search—features that are hard to reproduce faithfully without implementing substantial Git tooling and execution infrastructure. A simulator can cover management/workflow APIs well, but will only approximate true source-control behavior.
simulatable_features: User/org accounts, teams, memberships, roles and permissions (repo-level access, branch protection settings as configuration objects)
Repository CRUD (create/list/update/archive/delete), metadata (topics, visibility), and simple file tree metadata stubs
Issues: CRUD, labels, milestones, assignees, states, comments, reactions, cross-link references as stored relations
Pull requests: CRUD, states (open/closed/merged), reviewers, review comments (as discussion records), approvals/requests-changes statuses, merge method selection (recorded outcome without real merge)
Projects/boards: columns, cards, issue/PR linking, basic automation rules as data
Releases/tags as metadata objects (version strings, notes, assets metadata)
Webhooks configuration and delivery logs (simulate event emission and record deliveries)
Actions/CI: workflow definitions as stored text, workflow runs/jobs as records with timestamps, statuses, logs as short synthetic text
Repository settings: default branch, collaborators, deploy keys/SSH keys metadata, secrets metadata (not real secret values)
GitHub Pages configuration objects (source branch/folder, custom domain, build status as synthetic state)
Notifications/inbox: subscriptions, thread records, read/unread state
Basic audit log/event stream as synthetic records (who did what, when)
non_simulatable_features: Full Git object model and operations (real commits/trees/blobs, packfiles), accurate branching history, and faithful clone/fetch/push semantics
Real diff generation, 3-way merges, conflict detection/resolution, and code review anchored to exact line-level diffs across commits
Accurate search (code search, advanced query ranking, semantic navigation) based on a real index over repository contents
Actual CI/CD execution environment (runners, containers/VMs), artifact generation, caching, concurrency, and real build/test outputs
Security scanning and analysis requiring tooling/models (Dependabot ecosystem intelligence, CodeQL static analysis, secret scanning with real detectors and alert triage accuracy)
Package/container registries with real artifact storage, distribution, and integrity semantics (beyond metadata CRUD)
Git LFS and large binary storage/transfer behavior
Auth/security features that depend on real cryptography and trust chains (verified commits, SSO/SAML flows, signature verification) beyond superficial metadata flags

name: Gmail
description: Gmail is Google's email service offering powerful email management and organization tools. Users can compose, send, receive, and organize emails using labels, folders, and advanced search capabilities. The platform includes features like spam filtering, email threading, attachment handling, and integration with Google Calendar and Drive. Users can also set up filters and rules, manage multiple email accounts, create signatures, and use smart compose for faster email writing.
suitability_reasoning: Core entities and workflows (messages, threads, labels, drafts, contacts, filters, mailbox state) are highly structured and can be synthesized in SQLite and exposed via CRUD APIs. However, some of Gmail’s differentiating value relies on non-trivial intelligence or external integrations (spam/abuse detection, smart compose, complex search ranking/relevance, real attachment storage/virus scanning, and deep Calendar/Drive behavior), which are difficult to simulate faithfully beyond simple stubs.
simulatable_features: User accounts and mailbox settings (signatures, vacation responder, display density, conversation view on/off)
Mailboxes and system labels (INBOX, SENT, DRAFTS, SPAM, TRASH) plus custom labels
Email message CRUD: compose/create draft, update draft, send (state transition), receive (ingest), delete/archive
Conversation/thread modeling (group messages into threads, thread-level archive/mute, read/unread state)
Message metadata management (from/to/cc/bcc, subject, snippet, timestamps, flags like starred/important, headers as key-value pairs)
Read/unread, star/unstar, mark as spam/not spam, move to trash/restore (state transitions)
Basic attachment metadata CRUD (filename, mime_type, size, attachment_id) and linking attachments to messages (without real binary content)
Contacts and address book CRUD (names, emails, groups/labels for contacts)
Filters/rules CRUD (conditions like from/subject/has_words; actions like apply label, archive, mark read, forward-to (stub), delete)
Basic search endpoints over synthesized fields (query by sender, subject keywords, label, date range, has:attachment) with deterministic filtering
Multi-account management stubs (link external account entries, connection status, last_sync_time without real IMAP/POP)
Pagination, sorting, and batch operations (batch modify labels, mark read for a list of message IDs)
Notification preferences and simulated events (new mail event records, read receipts disabled/enabled as settings)
non_simulatable_features: Real spam/phishing/malware detection and adaptive filtering based on global signals (can only be approximated with static rules or random scoring)
Smart Compose / Smart Reply and other ML-driven writing assistance
Full-fidelity Gmail search relevance, ranking, and advanced operators matching Google’s behavior at scale
Real attachment storage, preview, conversion, and antivirus scanning of binary files (beyond metadata stubs)
End-to-end delivery via SMTP and real-world email interoperability (bounces, DKIM/DMARC, real routing)
Deep integrations with Google Calendar/Drive (creating events from emails, Drive-backed attachments) beyond mocked linkage records
Real-time sync across devices, offline mode, and conflict resolution semantics
Security features dependent on external infrastructure (OAuth risk analysis, suspicious login detection, advanced threat protection)

name: Twitter/X
description: Twitter (now X) is a real-time social media platform for sharing short messages and engaging in public conversations. Users can post tweets with text, images, videos, or polls, follow other users to see their updates, and engage through likes, retweets, and replies. The platform supports direct messaging for private conversations, trending topics exploration, hashtag usage, and list creation for organizing followed accounts. Users can also customize their profile, manage privacy settings, and use advanced search features.
suitability_reasoning: Many core objects and workflows are structured and CRUD-friendly (users, posts, follows, likes, reposts, replies, DMs, lists, blocks/mutes, notifications) and can be synthesized in SQLite. However, key user value depends on large-scale network effects and ranking/recommendation systems (timeline, trends, advanced search relevance, anti-spam, real-time virality). Those can be approximated with simple rules but not faithfully replicated without complex, non-synthesizable behavioral data and ranking models.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (bio, handle, avatar metadata, settings)
Post creation/edit/delete (text-only tweets; optional metadata for media/polls)
Replies/threads and conversation relationships (in_reply_to, quoting)
Likes, reposts/retweets, bookmarks
Follow/unfollow and follower/following lists
Mentions and hashtag parsing/storage
Lists (create/update/delete list; add/remove members; subscribe/unsubscribe)
Direct messages (1:1 and group threads; message send/delete; read receipts as flags)
Notifications (new follower, like, reply, repost, mention) as generated activity records
Privacy and safety controls (protected posts flag, who-can-reply settings, block, mute)
Basic reporting workflows (report content/user; status tracking of reports)
Basic media metadata management (store URLs/IDs, type, size, duration—without real hosting)
Account verification/subscription status as a simple attribute
Simple search over synthesized content (keyword search on posts/users/hashtags)
Basic analytics counters (impressions/engagement counts as stored or rule-generated numbers)
non_simulatable_features: Authentic real-time global timeline ranking and personalization (For You/Home) driven by large-scale ML
Trending topics computation at platform scale and in real time (requires massive live data + heuristics/ML)
High-fidelity spam/bot detection, abuse prevention, and integrity systems
Advanced search relevance and ranking comparable to production (signals, recency/authority scoring)
Virality and network effects reflecting real user behavior at internet scale
Real media delivery/processing (video transcoding, image hosting, streaming, content fingerprinting)
Copyright/DMCA enforcement pipelines and media matching
Identity/phone verification, fraud prevention, and payments/billing integrations (if modeling X subscriptions/ads end-to-end)
Real-time event ingestion and push delivery infrastructure (WebSockets/push notifications at scale)
Advertiser marketplace dynamics and auction-based ad serving optimization

name: LinkedIn
description: LinkedIn is the world's largest professional networking platform connecting professionals and businesses. Users can create detailed professional profiles showcasing their work experience, skills, education, and accomplishments. The platform enables job searching with advanced filters, networking with industry professionals, publishing articles, and engaging with professional content. Users can also receive and give recommendations, join professional groups, follow companies, and participate in industry discussions.
suitability_reasoning: LinkedIn has many structured, synthesizable entities (profiles, connections, companies, jobs, applications, messages, groups) that map well to CRUD APIs and relational data. However, several core user-facing behaviors depend on non-trivial ranking/recommendation systems (feed ordering, People You May Know, job recommendations, search relevance), trust/safety enforcement, and high-volume user-generated content dynamics that are hard to mimic faithfully without complex models. A useful simulation is still feasible by focusing on CRUD workflows and simplified search/filtering.
simulatable_features: User accounts and authentication sessions (simulated)
Professional profiles: headline, about, experience, education, certifications, projects, skills, languages
Connections graph: connect/accept/withdraw/remove, connection degree metadata
Recommendations and endorsements: create/read/update/delete recommendations; endorse/unendorse skills
Company pages: create/update company info, admins, locations, industries, followers
Following system: follow/unfollow people and companies
Job postings: create/update jobs, salary ranges, location/remote flags, required skills, seniority, employment type
Job search with basic filtering and pagination (keyword/location/industry/seniority/remote/date-posted)
Job applications: submit application, attach resume metadata, application status pipeline (submitted/review/interview/offer/rejected/withdrawn)
Recruiter workflows: candidate shortlists, notes/tags, pipeline stages (simplified ATS-like CRM)
Messaging: 1:1 and group conversations, messages, read receipts (optional), attachments metadata
Invitations/InMail credits as a simple quota counter (simulated)
Groups: create/join/leave groups, group roles, membership requests
Posts: create/edit/delete short posts, reactions, comments, reposts/shares (with short synthesized text)
Articles: create/edit/delete article metadata and short body text (limited length)
Events: create events, RSVP status, attendee lists
Notifications: generate notifications for connection requests, messages, comments, job application updates
Saved items: saved jobs, saved posts, saved searches
Reporting and moderation states as flags (reported content records, simple takedown status)
Basic analytics: follower counts, post impressions/likes counts (synthetic), applicant counts per job
non_simulatable_features: High-fidelity feed ranking/personalization (relevance scoring, diversity, freshness, interest modeling)
People You May Know and sophisticated network recommendations based on large-scale graph algorithms
Job matching/recommendations and applicant ranking using ML and proprietary signals
Search relevance at LinkedIn scale (learning-to-rank, spam detection, entity understanding)
Trust/safety and anti-abuse systems (spam/scam detection, bot detection, identity verification) beyond simple rule-based flags
Real-world identity and employment verification (background checks, credential verification)
Ads auction, targeting optimization, and conversion attribution at realistic fidelity (can be stubbed but not accurately simulated)
Rich content quality and long-form professional content ecosystem at real scale (can be faked, but not meaningfully equivalent)
External integrations and data sources (ATS integrations, email syncing, third-party enrichment) requiring real systems
Live labor market insights derived from global aggregated data (economic signals, trend analytics) beyond synthetic sampling

name: Reddit
description: Reddit is a massive discussion platform organized into thousands of topic-based communities called subreddits. Users can browse content, post text, links, images, or videos in relevant subreddits, and participate in discussions through comments. The platform uses an upvote/downvote system for content ranking, supports threaded discussions, and offers both public and private communities. Users can customize their feed, save posts, award exceptional content, and use search features to find specific discussions or communities.
suitability_reasoning: Reddit’s core data model (users, subreddits, posts, comments, votes, moderation actions, subscriptions, notifications) is highly structured and well-suited to CRUD-based simulation with synthesized data. However, key parts of the real experience depend on large-scale emergent behavior and content relevance (feed ranking, trend dynamics, spam/abuse, search relevance, and rich media hosting), which are difficult to reproduce faithfully without a real ranking/indexing system and large volumes of realistic content.
simulatable_features: user accounts and profiles (create/update, karma counters as derived fields)
subreddit entities (create/update, public/private/restricted flags, rules metadata)
membership and subscriptions (join/leave, favorites, mute)
post CRUD (text/link metadata, flair, NSFW flag, crosspost relationships)
comment CRUD with threading (parent/child relationships, collapse state as client-side metadata)
voting system (upvote/downvote, score aggregation, vote history per user)
saving/hiding posts and comments
reporting content (reports queue items, report reasons, status)
moderation actions (remove/approve posts/comments, lock threads, sticky posts, ban/mute users, mod logs)
user-to-user messaging (DM threads, inbox, read/unread)
notifications (mentions, replies, mod actions, message notifications)
awards as a virtual inventory/transactions model (give award, award counts, pseudo-balance)
basic subreddit/post listings with simple sort modes (new/top with fixed time windows, hot via simplified formula)
admin-like safety states (quarantine flags, content warnings) as metadata
non_simulatable_features: high-fidelity feed ranking and personalization (true ‘hot’ dynamics, recommendation systems, collaborative filtering)
realistic large-scale search relevance and autocomplete (requires a genuine search index and ranking tuned on real data)
trending/popularity discovery at real-world scale (front page dynamics, viral spread, brigading effects)
authentic long-form and media-rich content ecosystem at scale (the quality/variety of UGC; images/videos themselves)
robust anti-spam/abuse detection and ban evasion handling (ML/heuristics and adversarial behavior)
real-time chat presence and live discussion experiences at production scale
external link resolution/preview generation and media hosting/processing pipelines

name: Spotify
description: Spotify is a popular music streaming service with millions of songs, albums, and podcasts. Users can search for music by artist, song, or album, create and manage custom playlists, and discover new content through personalized recommendations. The platform supports following favorite artists, sharing music with friends, accessing lyrics, and controlling playback quality. Users can also save music for offline listening, use collaborative playlists, explore curated playlists by mood or genre, and listen to podcasts.
suitability_reasoning: Many user workflows are structured and CRUD-like (library, playlists, follows, subscriptions, playback settings) and can be populated with synthesized metadata. However, Spotify’s core value depends on non-synthesizable assets and services—audio/podcast media, licensing-driven availability, real recommendation models, and true full-catalog search/ranking—so a simulation must focus on management and metadata rather than actual streaming and ML-driven discovery.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update settings, country, plan, explicit-content setting)
Subscription plans, billing status, invoices, trial periods (CRUD over plan objects and payment records)
Music/podcast catalog metadata (artists, albums, tracks, podcasts, episodes with durations, genres, release dates, explicit flags)
User library actions (save/unsave tracks/albums/artists/episodes, liked songs)
Playlist CRUD (create/delete playlists, rename, description, public/private, reorder tracks, add/remove items)
Collaborative playlist management (invite collaborators, roles/permissions, change history metadata)
Following relationships (follow/unfollow artists/users, list followers/following)
Playback device/session state (active device, queue list, repeat/shuffle, volume, quality setting) as simulated state transitions
Offline download list management (mark items for offline, track download status/progress as synthetic states)
Listening history and play events (track plays, timestamps, skips, completion rate) as synthesized event logs
Content sharing artifacts (share links, messages/targets, share history)
Lyrics metadata presence/availability flags and short snippet lines (not full licensed lyrics) as attachable metadata
Curated playlist collections by mood/genre as static synthesized collections (browse endpoints)
User-generated ratings/thumbs for podcasts/episodes (where applicable) and simple feedback signals
non_simulatable_features: Actual audio/podcast streaming and DRM-licensed media delivery
Real catalog completeness and licensing/territory restrictions tied to real-world rights holders (can only be approximated synthetically)
Personalized recommendations, radio, Discover Weekly-style ranking driven by large-scale ML and collaborative filtering (can only be mocked with rules/randomness)
High-quality search relevance over millions of items with typo tolerance and learned ranking (can only be approximated with simple text matching)
Real-time audio analysis features (loudness/tempo derived from audio) if expected to reflect actual tracks (can be faked but not grounded)
Synchronized, fully accurate lyrics (time-coded and licensed) and karaoke-style features
Social/viral dynamics at scale (real friend activity feed signals, popularity trends) beyond synthetic approximations
External integrations dependent on proprietary clients/hardware (Spotify Connect behavior fidelity, car systems, smart speakers) beyond basic state simulation

name: Expedia
description: Expedia is a comprehensive online travel booking platform for planning and booking trips worldwide. Users can search and compare flights, hotels, rental cars, and vacation packages based on dates, destinations, and preferences. The platform provides detailed information including prices, reviews, photos, and amenities for each option. Users can manage their bookings, view itineraries, access mobile boarding passes, earn rewards points, and receive travel alerts. It also offers features like flexible date searches, bundle deals, and travel insurance options.
suitability_reasoning: Expedia’s core workflows are structured and transactional (searchable inventories, quotes, bookings, payments, cancellations, itineraries, rewards), which can be represented with relational entities and realistic synthesized data in SQLite. While real-time pricing/availability, external supplier connectivity, and rich media are not truly reproducible, a simulated environment can approximate them with generated inventories, rule-based pricing, and deterministic availability to support end-to-end user tasks.
simulatable_features: User accounts and traveler profiles (personal details, preferences, saved documents metadata)
Search and filtering over synthesized inventories (flights, hotels, cars, packages) by date, location, price, stops, amenities, ratings
Listings/details endpoints for flights/hotels/cars including amenities, policies, room types/fare classes, and basic review scores/counts
Price quotes and fare/room rate breakdowns (base, taxes/fees, add-ons) using rule-based calculations
Cart/checkout flow for single bookings and bundled deals (package builder, savings calculations)
Booking creation and lifecycle management (confirm, modify, cancel, refund status, rebook) with policies and deadlines
Itinerary management (trip timelines, segments/legs, hotel nights, car pickup/dropoff, confirmation numbers)
Payment method vault (tokenized/placeholder), invoices/receipts, transaction records, refunds
Travel insurance add-on selection and policy records (plan type, coverage summary, price)
Rewards program (points accrual/redemption, tier status, activity ledger)
Saved items/watchlists (saved hotels, flights, trips), price alerts as stored subscriptions
Notifications and travel alerts as generated events (gate changes, schedule updates, reminders) without real external triggers
Customer support tickets, messaging threads, and case status tracking
non_simulatable_features: True real-time airline/hotel/car supplier availability and inventory synchronization
Live, constantly changing market pricing and competitive fare shopping across external systems
Actual booking issuance with airlines (PNR generation with carriers), e-ticketing, and real boarding passes/QR codes accepted by airports
Real maps/navigation and geocoding/places data tied to external providers (can only be approximated with static synthesized locations)
Authentic user-generated content at scale (verbatim reviews) and sophisticated fraud/spam detection
High-fidelity property photos and media assets (only metadata or placeholder URLs can be simulated)
Real-time disruptions and alerts sourced from airlines/airports/weather providers (can only be simulated with scripted events)
Third-party identity verification, payments processing, chargeback networks, and tax/remittance compliance in different jurisdictions

name: Facebook
description: Facebook is a social networking platform where users create profiles, connect with friends, and share posts, photos, videos, Stories, Reels, and live streams in a personalized News Feed. It offers Groups, Pages, Events, and Marketplace for community building, broadcasting, event planning, and local buying/selling, with Messenger integrated for private and group chats. Users can react, comment, share, manage privacy settings, and businesses can run targeted ads, manage pages, and access analytics.
suitability_reasoning: Facebook contains many CRUD-friendly, highly structured domains that can be synthesized (users/profiles, friends, groups, pages, events, marketplace listings, messages, reactions/comments, privacy settings, notifications, basic ads objects and metrics). However, the platform’s core user value depends heavily on large-scale content distribution and ranking (personalized News Feed), rich media (photos/videos/live), real-time delivery, integrity systems, and ad targeting/auction behavior—features that are difficult to reproduce meaningfully without real content, scale, and complex algorithms. A simulated API can cover management workflows well but cannot authentically replicate feed relevance, virality, or media experiences.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update profile fields, settings, preferences)
Social graph management (friend requests, friends list, blocks, follows)
Posts as structured objects (text posts, metadata, visibility, tags) with CRUD
Comments and replies (threaded CRUD, moderation states)
Reactions/likes and shares (create/delete reactions, share objects, counts)
Groups (create groups, membership requests, roles/admins, group rules)
Pages (create/manage pages, roles, page posts, page settings)
Events (create events, RSVP status, guest lists, event updates)
Marketplace listings (items, categories, price, condition, location, availability, seller profiles)
Saved items/bookmarks and collections
Messenger-like messaging (1:1 and group threads, messages, read receipts as states, attachments as metadata placeholders)
Notifications (activity notifications as records; mark read/unread)
Privacy controls as policy objects (audience selectors, allow/deny lists) and enforcement at API level
Basic reporting/insights as synthesized aggregates (page views, post reach, engagement counts over time)
Ads management objects (ad accounts, campaigns, ad sets, ads, budgets, schedules, statuses) with synthetic performance metrics
Moderation/admin tools (report content, hide/delete, warnings, bans, audit logs)
Search-like directory endpoints over synthetic data (simple filtering by name/category/location without real ranking)
non_simulatable_features: Personalized News Feed ranking and recommendation quality (virality, relevance, ML-driven ranking, exploration)
Reels/Stories discovery algorithms and retention-optimized content sequencing
Authentic large-scale content ecosystem (diverse real user content at scale, trends, memes, cultural context)
Real media handling as a product feature (photo/video storage/encoding/streaming, live streams, playback, DRM); only metadata can be faked
Real-time presence and delivery guarantees at Facebook scale (typing indicators, multi-device sync latency, push infrastructure) beyond basic state simulation
Ad targeting/auction dynamics (lookalike audiences, conversion modeling, real attribution, bidding competition) beyond simplified rule-based simulation
Advanced integrity systems (spam detection, bot detection, coordinated inauthentic behavior, misinformation classifiers) beyond simple heuristic flags
Graph-based recommendations (People You May Know, group/page recommendations) with realistic ML behavior
Cross-app integrations and external measurement (Pixel, SDK events, real conversion tracking) beyond synthetic events
Robust multilingual content understanding and content policy enforcement at production fidelity

name: Yahoo
description: Yahoo is a web portal and online media platform offering personalized news, finance, sports, entertainment, and weather. Users can read articles and watch videos, track markets with real-time quotes, charts, portfolios, and alerts in Yahoo Finance, follow live scores, schedules, standings, and fantasy leagues in Yahoo Sports, access Yahoo Mail for email with contacts and calendar, use the search engine to find web content, and customize a homepage with topics and local weather. Signing in with a Yahoo account enables personalization and syncing across web and mobile apps.
suitability_reasoning: Yahoo is a bundle of multiple products. Several parts are highly simulatable with structured CRUD data (Mail, Contacts, Calendar, homepage personalization, Finance portfolios/watchlists/alerts, Fantasy league management). However, core portal value relies on non-synthesizable or hard-to-replicate components such as real news article/video content, real-time market quotes, live sports feeds, and web search indexing/ranking. A simulated environment can focus on the account, organization, and tracking workflows rather than the real content feeds.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, preferences, and personalization settings (topics followed, regions, notification settings)
Homepage module layout customization (widgets, ordering, enabled/disabled sections)
Yahoo Mail management primitives: mailboxes/folders/labels, messages metadata (from/to/subject/date), read/unread, star/flag, drafts, sending (simulated), attachments metadata
Contacts/address book CRUD (names, emails, phone numbers, groups)
Calendar CRUD (calendars, events, invites/RSVP status, reminders)
Finance watchlists, portfolios, holdings, transactions (buy/sell records), price alerts (trigger rules), saved charts/time ranges (as user settings)
Finance static/historical market data tables (synthetic OHLC candles, volumes) and company profiles metadata (tickers, sectors) with plausible values (not real-time)
Sports favorites (teams/players followed), saved schedules/standings tables (synthetic), notification/score alert preferences
Fantasy sports league management: leagues, teams, rosters, drafts (simulated), waivers/trades, matchups, scoring settings, standings (synthetic)
Saved searches within the app (query history) and content preference settings (safe search, region/language) as user-configurable data
Notification center: alerts objects for mail, finance, sports, weather with read/dismiss state
Weather locations list, units preferences, saved places, synthetic forecasts/conditions records
non_simulatable_features: Real news, sports, and entertainment editorial article content at scale (long-form, constantly updated) and the full recommendation/curation quality of the feed
Streaming/hosting and playback of actual media content (videos) beyond metadata
Real-time market quotes, real-time charts, and exchange-grade latency/accuracy; real corporate actions/news impacting prices
Live sports scores, play-by-play, and real-time schedule updates sourced from external feeds

suitability_reasoning: Canva has many structured, CRUD-friendly objects (users/teams, projects, folders, templates metadata, brand kits, comments, permissions, schedules, exports) that are easy to synthesize in a SQLite-backed API simulation. suitability_reasoning: Goodreads has many structured, CRUD-friendly entities (users, books, shelves, reviews, ratings, reading status, progress updates, groups, discussions, challenges) that can be synthesized realistically in a SQLite-backed simulation. However, core user value also relies on large-scale real bibliographic coverage, high-quality long-form reviews, and personalized recommendations driven by behavioral data and ranking logic; these can be approximated but not faithfully reproduced without a real corpus and recommendation models/search relevance.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (settings, preferences, privacy controls)
Book catalog records (title, authors, series, genres, publication metadata, ISBNs, edition records) with synthesized bibliographic data
Author profiles (bio snippet, social links metadata, claimed books, Q&A posts as short text)
Shelves and shelf management (default shelves, custom shelves, tags, sorting, visibility)
Reading status workflows (Want to Read / Currently Reading / Read) and history
Reading progress tracking (percent/page, start/end dates, status updates, rereads)
Ratings (1–5 stars) and aggregated statistics (average rating, rating counts) computed from synthesized user ratings
Reviews (short-to-medium text), comments on reviews, likes/upvotes
Follow/friend relationships and basic activity feed events (user X rated book Y, added to shelf, posted update)
Groups (create/join/leave), roles (owner/mod/member), group membership management
Discussion boards/topics/posts/replies within groups (CRUD threads and replies; moderation actions)
Reading challenges (create/join challenge, set goal, track progress, completion status, leaderboards with synthesized scoring)
Lists and listopia-like collections (create list, add/remove books, vote/rank) with synthesized content
Notifications (new comment, friend activity, group updates) as stored events
Basic search endpoints over the simulated dataset (query books/authors/genres) using simple matching
Import/export of a user's library (simulated CSV upload processing into shelves/reading history)
non_simulatable_features: True real-world completeness/accuracy of the global book database (coverage of millions of real titles/editions, authoritative metadata)
High-quality, authentic long-form reviews at scale (while you can store text, you cannot replicate real community content/voice meaningfully)
Personalized recommendation quality (collaborative filtering/model-based ranking) beyond simplistic heuristic recommendations
Search relevance comparable to production (ranking, typo tolerance, deduping editions/works, knowledge graph disambiguation at scale)
Spam/abuse detection, trust/safety systems, and sophisticated moderation automation
External integrations and real-time sync (Kindle/Amazon ecosystem, publisher feeds, real author verification processes)
Real-world events/promotions and marketing campaigns tied to actual releases and author presence

name: Uber
description: Uber is a ride-hailing platform where users set pickup and dropoff locations, select ride types, view price estimates and ETA, and then request, track, and cancel rides. After trips, riders can rate drivers, leave feedback, and split fares. Drivers manage their availability, accept or decline requests, navigate routes, and view earnings. The platform handles fare calculation, payments, receipts, safety features, and support workflows like reporting issues or lost items.
suitability_reasoning: Most core workflows are structured and can be synthesized with realistic fake data: users, drivers, vehicles, trip requests, statuses, ETAs, fares, payments, receipts, ratings, and support tickets. The main limitations are features that depend on real-time GPS movement, routing/traffic, fraud detection, and external payment/identity systems; these can be approximated but not reproduced faithfully without complex simulations or third-party services.

Fare calculation breakdown (base fare, per-mile, per-minute, fees, tolls as synthetic, surge, discounts, tips)
Payments and billing records (payment methods metadata, charges, refunds, receipts)
Cancellations and cancellation fees (policy rules, timestamps, reasons)
Ratings and short feedback (star ratings, tags, short comments)

Promotions/credits (coupon creation, eligibility, redemption)

non_simulatable_features: Real-world GPS tracking and continuous live location streaming with accurate movement

Real-time safety monitoring/telemetry and incident detection (e.g., crash detection) beyond event stubs

name: Airbnb
description: Airbnb is a marketplace for short-term stays and experiences. Guests can search and filter listings by location, dates, price, property type, and amenities, then view detailed pages with photos, descriptions, house rules, and reviews. They submit booking requests or use instant book, manage trips, send messages to hosts, and handle cancellations or changes. Hosts can create and edit listings, set pricing and availability, manage calendars, respond to inquiries, and review guests. The platform manages payments, identity checks, and dispute resolution.
suitability_reasoning: Airbnb’s core workflows are structured and transactional (listings, availability calendars, bookings, payments, messaging, reviews, cancellations), which map cleanly to a relational schema and RESTful CRUD APIs. Most data can be synthesized realistically (prices, dates, locations, amenities, policies, statuses). The main limitations are media (photos), real identity verification, fraud/risk scoring, and complex real-world payment/dispute operations, which can be stubbed but not fully replicated.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (guest/host), preferences, verification status flags
Listing CRUD (title, description, address/city/geo, property type, room type, capacity, amenities, house rules, check-in/out windows)
Pricing configuration (base price, seasonal rates, weekend multipliers, cleaning fee, extra guest fees, discounts, minimum/maximum stay rules)
Availability calendar management (blocked dates, custom nightly prices, booking windows, preparation time)
Search and filtering over synthesized listing attributes (location bounding box/city, dates, price range, property type, amenities, occupancy)
Booking request / instant book flows (reservation creation, approval/decline, status transitions, confirmation codes)
Trip management (itineraries, reservation modifications, special requests, check-in instructions text fields)
Cancellations and refunds (policy types, cancellation reasons, computed refund amounts, timelines)
Messaging between guest and host (threads, messages, read receipts, attachments metadata placeholders)
Reviews and ratings (overall score, sub-ratings, short text, review eligibility rules after checkout)
Host tools (inquiry management, response tracking, acceptance rate metrics computed from data)
Payments ledger simulation (charges, holds, payouts, service fees, taxes as numeric fields; payment status transitions)
Experiences CRUD (experience listings, schedules, capacity, bookings) using the same reservation model
Dispute/case records (case creation, evidence text fields, status workflow, support agent assignment)
Notifications (email/push/in-app) as stored events with delivery status
non_simulatable_features: Real photo hosting/processing and image content (can only simulate URLs/metadata, not authentic media)
True identity verification (government ID checks, biometric validation) and third-party KYC integrations
Fraud detection, risk scoring, and trust/safety ML-driven decisions (can only stub outcomes)
Real payment processing and banking network interactions (card authorization, chargebacks, payouts timing/settlement)
Accurate tax calculation/remittance across jurisdictions and legal compliance logic (can only approximate with rules)
Real-time availability synchronization with external property management systems and channel managers
Phone/SMS deliverability and telecom verification (can only simulate message records)
Live customer support operations (human moderation, investigation outcomes) beyond scripted workflows
Geocoding accuracy and map rendering from real providers (can only store lat/long and basic proximity filtering)
Enforcement of complex local regulations (permits, zoning, short-term rental laws) beyond simplified flags

name: Trello
description: Trello is a visual project and task management tool based on boards, lists, and cards. Users create boards for projects, add lists to represent stages, and cards for tasks, which can be moved across lists to show progress. Cards support descriptions, checklists, attachments, labels, due dates, and assignees. Teams can comment, mention members, and subscribe to updates. Power-Ups and automations add features like custom fields, rules, integrations, and calendar views.
suitability_reasoning: Trello’s core value is structured CRUD over highly synthesizable entities (workspaces/boards/lists/cards) with clear relationships and state transitions (card movement, statuses, assignments, due dates). Most workflows can be fully represented with a SQLite schema and REST endpoints. Advanced integrations/Power-Ups and real-time collaboration aspects can be approximated but external third-party behavior and real-time event delivery are not fully reproducible without additional infrastructure.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, and authentication tokens (simulated)
Workspaces/teams creation and membership management
Role-based access control (admin/member/observer) and board visibility (private/workspace/public)
Boards CRUD, board settings, and templates (as structured metadata)
Lists CRUD and list ordering within boards
Cards CRUD with position/order, moving cards across lists, and archiving/unarchiving
Card fields: title, description, due date, start date, reminders (as timestamps/flags), cover metadata
Assignees/members on cards and watchers/subscriptions
Labels CRUD and label assignment to cards
Checklists and checklist items CRUD with completion state
Comments on cards, mentions (as parsed text/metadata), and activity logs
Attachments metadata CRUD (filename, URL placeholder, size, mime type) and association to cards
Custom fields (as schema-less key/value definitions per board) and per-card values
Board/card search and filtering (by label, member, due date, text) using database queries
Notifications/inbox as stored events (create/update/comment/mention) retrievable via API
Simple automation rules engine (simulated): triggers (card moved, due date reached) -> actions (add label, assign member, move card)
Exports/imports as generated JSON/CSV representations of entities (simulated)
Calendar view data endpoints derived from due/start dates (data only)
non_simulatable_features: True real-time collaboration guarantees (live cursor/instant sync across clients) without a websocket/event system; can only be approximated with polling
Third-party Power-Ups and external integrations (Slack, Google Drive, Jira, etc.) with real external side effects; only mock connectors are feasible
File storage/preview/virus scanning and rich attachment rendering (can simulate metadata, not actual storage and preview pipelines)
Email-to-board ingestion and inbound email parsing/delivery (can be stubbed, not fully replicated)
Push notification delivery to devices (APNs/FCM) and email delivery (can be represented as queued messages only)
Enterprise-grade audit/retention/compliance features tied to real org policies and identity providers (SAML/SCIM) beyond simplified simulation
Sophisticated automation with complex conditions, rate limits, and execution semantics identical to Trello Butler; only simplified rules are practical

name: Stripe
description: Stripe is an online payments platform that enables businesses to accept and manage payments. Users can create customers, store payment methods, charge cards, set up subscriptions, issue refunds, and handle invoices and payouts. Dashboards show balances, payouts, disputes, and detailed transaction histories with filters and exports. Developers integrate Stripe via APIs and webhooks to support checkout flows, billing, and marketplace payouts, with configuration for tax, currencies, risk rules, and compliance.
suitability_reasoning: Stripe’s core product is structured financial objects and stateful workflows (customers, payment methods, charges, refunds, subscriptions, invoices, payouts, disputes) that map cleanly to relational data and CRUD+state-transition APIs. Transaction histories, balances, and lifecycle events can be synthesized realistically. The main limits are features requiring external banking/card networks, real identity verification, tax jurisdiction logic, and sophisticated risk/ML decisions; those can be stubbed with deterministic rules and simulated statuses/events without needing real-world connectivity.

non_simulatable_features: Actual card network and bank rail processing (authorization/settlement, real declines, interchange fees) beyond scripted simulation

name: Robinhood
description: Robinhood is a commission-free investing platform where users can search for stocks, ETFs, options, and cryptocurrencies, view quotes and charts, and place market or limit orders. suitability_reasoning: Most core workflows are structured, stateful CRUD operations over highly synthesizable entities (accounts, positions, orders, trades, transfers, instruments, watchlists, alerts). Market prices, charts, and corporate actions can be generated as plausible time-series data. The main gaps are features that depend on real-time market connectivity, best-execution/venue routing, and proprietary or third-party content (news/education) which are not essential to simulate the operational trading lifecycle.

name: Calendly
description: Calendly is an automated scheduling platform that lets users define event types with duration, locations (in-person or online), and availability rules, then share booking links. Invitees pick a time from free slots synced with connected calendars, automatically creating events and sending confirmations. suitability_reasoning: Calendly’s core workflows are structured CRUD over highly synthesizable entities (users, event types, availability rules, bookings, invitees, questions, reminders, policies). name: Stack Overflow
description: Stack Overflow is a Q&A platform for developers where users ask programming questions, tag them by technology, and post code and explanations. Others can answer, comment, and edit content collaboratively. Voting, acceptance, and reputation systems surface high-quality answers and unlock privileges. Users can bookmark questions, follow tags, and search across the knowledge base. Teams and enterprises can create private spaces with dedicated moderation and analytics.
suitability_reasoning: Stack Overflow’s core data model (users, questions, answers, comments, tags, votes, reputation, badges, moderation flags) is highly structured and CRUD-friendly, so a realistic simulated environment is feasible. However, the platform’s primary value depends on a large corpus of high-quality long-form technical content, nuanced duplicate/quality judgments, and sophisticated search/ranking, which are hard to meaningfully synthesize without losing realism. A simulation can focus on workflows and mechanics (posting, editing, voting, moderation, permissions) rather than replicating the real knowledge base quality.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (display name, bio, developer role, settings)
Question CRUD (title, body, code blocks, tags, status: open/closed/duplicate)

Comments CRUD on questions/answers
Tag management (create tags, tag synonyms/aliases, tag following/ignored tags)
Voting system (upvote/downvote) and vote audit trails
Acceptance workflow (question owner accepts/unaccepts an answer)
Reputation and badge awarding rules (synthetic but consistent point changes and thresholds)
Bookmarks/favorites and reading lists
User privileges/roles based on reputation (e.g., can comment, edit, close-vote)
Edits and suggested edits with review/approval queues
Moderation workflows (flags, close votes, reopen votes, delete/undelete, suspension records)
Post history and revisions (diff metadata, editor, timestamps)
Basic search endpoints over synthetic content (keyword/tag filters) without real ranking parity
Teams/private spaces (teams, memberships, permissions, private posts) and basic analytics counters
non_simulatable_features: A truly realistic large-scale corpus of authoritative programming Q&A content comparable to the real site

Real-time popularity/trending signals derived from global traffic patterns
External integrations and identity/SSO behaviors in enterprise contexts (can be mocked, but not fully replicated)
AI-assisted or semantic features (if present) that rely on trained models or embeddings for meaning-based retrieval

name: GitLab
description: GitLab is a DevOps platform centered on Git repositories, issues, and CI/CD pipelines. Users create projects, push code, manage branches, open merge requests, review diffs, and handle approvals. Issues and boards track work, with labels, milestones, and assignees. Built-in pipelines automate testing and deployment, and environments show deployment status. Permissions, groups, and project settings manage access, integrations, and security features like code scanning and approvals.
suitability_reasoning: GitLab’s core workflows are largely structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (projects, repos/branches, merge requests, issues, labels, pipelines, jobs, environments, users/groups/permissions). These map cleanly to relational data and REST endpoints. What’s hard to faithfully simulate is the true Git object model/diff/merge behavior and real CI execution/security scanning, but you can still simulate them as state machines with plausible metadata and logs, enabling realistic task completion without running real builds or storing real code history.
simulatable_features: Users, SSH keys, access tokens (CRUD, scopes, expiration)
Groups, subgroups, memberships, roles/permissions (RBAC)
Projects (create/archive/transfer), project settings (visibility, default branch, merge policies)
Repository metadata layer: branches/tags (create/delete), commits (synthetic), files (synthetic blobs), releases (version, notes, assets metadata)

Merge requests: creation, status transitions (draft/open/merged/closed), reviewers/assignees, approvals, approval rules, discussions/comments, simple diff metadata (files changed, lines added/removed)
Issues: CRUD, states, assignees, due dates, time tracking fields, comments, relationships (links/blocks), epics (if modeled)
Boards: lists/columns, issue positioning, swimlanes as metadata
Labels and milestones (project/group scoped), issue/MR labeling and milestone assignment
Pipelines: create/trigger (push/MR/schedule/manual), pipeline status, stages, jobs, retries/cancels, artifacts metadata, job logs as stored text
Runners registry (registered runners, tags, online/offline status) as synthetic resources
Environments and deployments: environment CRUD, deployment records, statuses, rollbacks as state transitions, last-deployed info
CI/CD variables and secrets metadata (store masked placeholder values), protected branches/tags rules
Webhooks/integrations configuration records (URLs, events) without actual external calls
Package/container registry metadata: packages, versions, download counts, manifests as metadata
Audit events (synthetic) and activity feeds (derived from stored events)
Wiki pages and snippets as short text content
Basic security/compliance records as metadata: vulnerabilities list, severities, findings, approval requirements, policy objects
non_simulatable_features: Full-fidelity Git behavior: true commit DAG integrity, merges/rebases/cherry-picks with conflict resolution, binary delta storage, and exact diff computation over real file contents at scale
Actual CI/CD execution: running builds/tests, executing scripts, producing real artifacts, interacting with real runners/kubernetes/cloud providers
Real security scanning and SAST/DAST/secret detection results generated from code analysis (can only be faked as findings metadata)
Accurate code review UX semantics derived from real diffs/blame/inline comments anchored to exact line hashes (can only be approximated)
Real-time event streaming and performance characteristics (websocket updates, trace views, live job logs) beyond static/polled APIs
Third-party integrations that require external systems (LDAP/SAML auth, Jira syncing, Slack notifications, cloud deployments) beyond storing configuration and simulated callbacks
Advanced analytics/insights that require aggregating large real histories (cycle analytics, code ownership metrics, DORA metrics) unless simplified to synthetic aggregates

name: Uber Eats

name: QuickBooks
description: QuickBooks is an accounting and bookkeeping platform for small businesses. Users can create and send invoices, track payments and expenses, categorize transactions, reconcile bank accounts, and manage customers and vendors. The system generates financial reports such as profit and loss, balance sheets, and cash flow. Payroll, tax, and inventory modules manage employees, filing, and stock. Multi-user access, roles, and audit trails support collaboration and compliance.
suitability_reasoning: QuickBooks is centered on highly structured, relational business data (customers, vendors, invoices, bills, accounts, transactions, payroll records, inventory items) and well-defined workflows (invoice-to-cash, bill-to-pay, reconciliation, period close). This data is straightforward to synthesize realistically in SQLite and expose via REST CRUD endpoints. While some integrations (live bank feeds, payments rails, tax filing) and complex accounting edge cases are hard to fully replicate, the core product experience can be simulated well with synthesized ledgers, transactions, and reports computed from stored data.
simulatable_features: User accounts, companies/books, multi-entity setups (subsidiaries/classes/locations as simplified dimensions)
Role-based access control (users, roles, permissions) and multi-user collaboration

Vendor/supplier management (profiles, payment terms, 1099 flags as metadata)

Recurring transactions/templates and scheduled generation
Bank accounts (registers) and imported bank transactions as synthetic feeds
Bank reconciliation workflows (statement periods, matched/unmatched transactions, reconciliation status)

Inventory items/products/services catalog (SKUs, costs, sales prices, quantity on hand)

name: Jira
description: Jira is a project and issue tracking platform widely used for software development. Users create projects and configure workflows with states like To Do, In Progress, and Done, then create issues for tasks, bugs, or stories. Issues have fields such as assignee, priority, labels, sprints, and estimates, plus comments and attachments. Scrum and Kanban boards, backlogs, and reports help teams plan and track work. Admins manage schemes, permissions, integrations, and automation rules.
suitability_reasoning: Jira’s core value is managing structured, user-generated entities (projects, issues, workflows, sprints, boards, comments) with clear relationships and state transitions. Nearly all key behaviors can be represented as CRUD plus a few action endpoints (transition issue state, move issue to sprint/backlog). Data is highly synthesizable (statuses, priorities, estimates, timestamps, users, links), enabling realistic workflows without external real-time dependencies. Some advanced features (complex JQL semantics, marketplace integrations, and rich attachment handling) are harder to fully replicate but are not required for a useful simulation.
simulatable_features: User, team, and role management (create users, assign to groups/roles)
Project creation and configuration (project keys, types, components, versions)
Issue CRUD (epic/story/task/bug), including fields like assignee, reporter, priority, labels, due date, estimates, custom fields
Issue relationships (parent/child, epic links, blocks/duplicates/relates links)
Workflow modeling (statuses, transitions, resolution fields) and issue state transitions
Backlog and sprint management (create sprints, start/complete, move issues between backlog and sprints, sprint ranking/order)
Kanban board columns and WIP limits (store and update board/column config; move issues across columns via transitions)
Comments and mentions (CRUD comments, basic @mention metadata)
Worklogs/time tracking (log time, edit/delete worklogs, remaining estimate updates)
Attachments metadata (record attachment entries with filenames, sizes, mime types, upload timestamps; optionally store as blobs in SQLite)
Notifications and watchers (watch/unwatch issues, store notification events)
Permissions and schemes (simulate project permissions, issue security levels, roles; enforce basic access control in API)
Issue search with simplified filtering (by project, status, assignee, label, sprint, priority, text contains) as a subset of JQL
Dashboards and reports using synthesized aggregates (burndown data, velocity, cumulative flow computed from stored issue history)
Audit logs (record admin/config changes and issue events)
Automation rules in a simplified form (if status changes then assign, transition, comment; scheduled rules) with deterministic execution
non_simulatable_features: Full fidelity JQL (complete grammar, advanced functions, permissions-aware ranking, performance characteristics)
Marketplace app ecosystem and real third-party integrations (Slack/GitHub/Bitbucket/CI providers) beyond mocked webhook endpoints
Email ingestion and outbound email deliverability (can be stubbed, not truly replicated end-to-end)
Rich real-time collaboration and UI behaviors (live updates, drag-and-drop nuances) beyond representing state changes via APIs
Advanced automation engine parity (complex branching, smart values, entity properties, cross-project scalability and timing guarantees)
Native file storage/CDN behavior for large attachments (streaming, antivirus scanning, preview generation, retention policies)
Atlassian Cloud organization-wide features and identity (SSO/SAML/SCIM) in full depth (can be approximated but not truly equivalent)
Advanced analytics and machine-learning-driven insights (predictive estimates, anomaly detection) if present in specific Jira editions

name: Google Calendar
description: Google Calendar is an online calendar and scheduling tool where users create events with titles, times, locations, guests, and video conferencing links. They can manage multiple calendars, share calendars with others, set notifications and reminders, and adjust visibility. Events support recurring rules, descriptions, attachments, and responses (RSVP). Users can search events, view by day/week/month, and integrate with other apps to auto-create meetings and reminders.
suitability_reasoning: Google Calendar’s core value is structured, user-created data (calendars, events, attendees, recurrence rules, reminders, sharing/permissions) with clear entity relationships and state transitions, all of which can be synthesized realistically in a SQLite-backed REST API. Most workflows are CRUD-centric (create/update/cancel events, invite/RSVP, manage calendars/sharing) and do not require real-time external feeds. Some integrations (video conferencing provisioning, email delivery, external app sync) are better represented as mocked side effects rather than fully reproduced.

Calendar sharing and permissions (owner/writer/reader/free-busy, domain/public flags)
Event CRUD (title, description, start/end, all-day, location, visibility, status)
Recurring events with RRULE-like patterns and exception instances (exdates, modified occurrences)

name: Ticketmaster
description: Ticketmaster is a ticketing platform for concerts, sports, and live events. Users search by artist, team, venue, or date, then choose events, select seats on a map or via price filters, and complete purchases. They can view and manage orders, download or add tickets to mobile wallets, transfer tickets, and in some cases resell them. Event organizers manage inventory, pricing, presales, and access controls. The system handles payments, delivery methods, and anti-fraud checks.
suitability_reasoning: Ticketing is dominated by structured, relational data and transactional CRUD workflows (events, venues, seat inventory, offers/prices, carts, orders, tickets, transfers, and resale listings). These can be synthesized realistically in SQLite with deterministic business rules. Some peripheral capabilities (real payment networks, barcode cryptography, wallet integrations, and sophisticated fraud detection) are not meaningfully reproducible, but they can be stubbed while preserving end-to-end user tasks.

Browse/search events by artist/team/venue/date/category (simulated search endpoints with filters/sorts)
Venue and seating charts as structured sections/rows/seats; seat availability status and holds
Ticket types and offers (price levels, fees, taxes, accessible seating flags, quantity limits)
Presale codes and access windows; eligibility rules per user/segment
Cart creation, add/remove seats or GA quantities, cart expiration timers (simulated), and fee breakdown

Ticket issuance as digital assets (ticket records with barcodes as synthetic strings), delivery method selection (mobile/print/will-call as statuses)
Order history, order details, refunds/voids (rule-based), and customer support case records
Ticket transfer workflow: create transfer, accept/decline, revoke, recipient accounts, transfer status tracking
Resale marketplace: create listing, set price, listing status, purchase resale ticket, payout status (simulated)

non_simulatable_features: Real-time integration with external venue turnstile systems and live admission scanning behavior at scale

Advanced anti-fraud and bot mitigation (behavioral analytics, device fingerprinting, ML scoring) beyond simple rule simulation
Real-world seat map rendering/interactive UX and map-based selection nuances (API can represent seat geometry but not full UI behavior)
Real-time dynamic pricing algorithms and demand forecasting driven by proprietary models (can approximate with rules but not replicate)
Identity verification/know-your-customer checks for certain events/regions when dependent on third-party services (stubbed)

name: Instacart
description: Instacart is a grocery delivery and pickup service. Users select a store, browse categories or search for products, adjust quantities, and add items to a cart. suitability_reasoning: Instacart’s core workflows are structured CRUD-friendly operations over synthesizable entities (stores, products, carts, orders, deliveries, substitutions, payments, tips, messages, ratings). The main non-simulatable aspects are true real-time logistics/driver location and real payment processing, but these can be approximated with state transitions and synthetic events without harming task realism for an API simulation.

Actual phone/SMS/push delivery through external providers (can be represented as logged notification events only)
Human shopper judgment and nuanced replacement decisions beyond predefined rules (can be approximated with scripted outcomes)
Real-time marketplace dynamics (actual shopper supply, demand-based surge pricing) unless modeled with simplified synthetic rules

name: Patreon
description: Patreon is a membership platform that allows creators to offer subscription-based access to content and benefits. Creators set up pages with tiers, pricing, and rewards, then publish posts, audio, video, and other perks for patrons. Patrons can subscribe, manage memberships across creators, access exclusive content, comment, and message creators. The platform manages payments, billing cycles, and fraud checks, while creators can view analytics, payouts, and patron lists.
suitability_reasoning: Patreon’s core membership, tiering, patron management, billing cycles, payouts, and access-control workflows map well to synthesizable, structured CRUD data (users, creators, tiers, subscriptions, invoices, transactions, entitlements). However, a significant part of the real product value involves rich media hosting/streaming, content moderation, fraud/risk systems, and real payment network interactions, which are hard to faithfully replicate without external services. A simulated environment can still cover most user workflows by modeling content as metadata/URLs and simulating payment states and risk outcomes.

benefits/perks tracking (deliverable items, status, fulfillment notes, shipping address fields as text)
billing artifacts (invoices, line items, taxes/fees as numeric fields, payment status transitions)

payout settings and payout events (balance, pending/available amounts, payout schedules, payout status)
creator patron list management (search/filter, membership status, join date, lifetime value fields)
basic analytics dashboards (synthetic aggregates: revenue over time, churn, new patrons, top tiers)

non_simulatable_features: actual payment processing with card networks/banks (authorization, settlement, chargebacks in real time)
fraud detection/risk scoring and identity verification based on real signals (device fingerprinting, network reputation)
rich media hosting, transcoding, streaming, and DRM for audio/video (beyond storing metadata pointers)
copyright enforcement systems (e.g., automated matching) and real moderation pipelines at scale
real email/SMS/push delivery infrastructure and deliverability behavior (can only be mocked)
tax/VAT compliance and jurisdiction-specific rules as implemented in production (can only be approximated)
real recommendation/ranking/personalization of creator discovery feeds (can be stubbed but not authentic)
integration-dependent workflows (e.g., real Discord role sync, third-party fulfillment/shipping providers)

name: KAYAK
description: KAYAK is a travel search and booking aggregator that lets users search flights, hotels, and rental cars across multiple providers. Users can filter by price, times, airlines, stops, amenities, and ratings, then click through to complete bookings or book directly when available. Features include fare alerts, price tracking, trip planning, and itinerary management. The platform compares options, saves searches, and aggregates reservations into unified trip views.
suitability_reasoning: Most of KAYAK’s core user workflows can be represented with structured, synthesizable entities (flights/hotels/cars, search queries, results, bookings, itineraries, alerts, price histories) and clear CRUD relationships. While true real-world comparison requires live provider inventory, affiliate click-through behavior, and real pricing/availability, a simulated environment can generate plausible schedules, prices, inventory, and state transitions that preserve the interaction patterns users and agents rely on.

Flight/hotel/car search requests (origin/destination/dates/guests/cabin class) stored as search objects

Synthesized search results for flights/hotels/cars with fare rules, baggage, cancellation/refundability flags, room types, car classes, vendor info
Price calendars and historical price tracking using generated time series per route/property
Fare/price alerts (create/update/delete alert rules; trigger notifications based on simulated price changes)
Saved searches and recently viewed items
Trip planning: create trips, add segments (flight/hotel/car), notes, travelers, and attachments metadata
Itinerary management: import/store reservations (PNR-like codes, confirmation numbers), unify into a trip view, update/cancel reservation status
Booking flow simulation: quote -> hold -> book -> cancel/refund state transitions with payment tokens (mocked) and policy constraints
Provider comparison metadata (merchant/provider identifiers, deeplink URLs, booking channels) as static fields
User reviews/ratings metadata for hotels (short text + numeric ratings) and basic property/car attributes
Notifications center (read/unread, delivery channel preferences) and audit logs of price changes and booking actions
non_simulatable_features: Real-time inventory, pricing, and availability across multiple external providers (GDS/OTAs/hotel CRS/car systems)
True meta-search ranking and relevance that depends on proprietary algorithms, partner bids, and live market conditions

Actual payments, fraud checks, chargebacks, and PCI-compliant processing (can only be mocked)
Real-time disruptions and operational data (delays, cancellations, gate changes) unless artificially generated
Email scanning/automatic itinerary import from real inboxes and parsing of arbitrary vendor emails (can only be approximated with synthetic inputs)
Production-grade geo/POI intelligence (nearby attractions, commute times, real map routing) unless reduced to static synthesized data
Partner-specific promotions, loyalty pricing, member-only rates, and contract-driven merchandising rules tied to real agreements

name: Lyft
description: Lyft is a ride-hailing platform where users set pickup and dropoff locations, choose ride options, view pricing and ETAs, and request, track, or cancel rides. Riders can split fares, tip drivers, rate trips, and manage payment methods and preferences. Drivers manage availability, accept rides, navigate routes, and review earnings and incentives. Safety features include trip sharing, emergency options, and support flows for reporting issues.
suitability_reasoning: Lyft’s core workflows are structured and transactional (users, drivers, vehicles, ride requests, quotes, trips, payments, ratings, support cases) and can be represented with synthesized yet realistic data in a relational schema and CRUD-style REST APIs. The main challenges are true real-time dynamics (live GPS streams, traffic-based ETAs/pricing, and telephony/emergency integrations), but these can be approximated deterministically or via scripted state transitions in a simulator without requiring external data feeds.
